The total includes a small number (around 2%) of destitute removals and criminal deportations - these people are not necessarily overstayers or unlawfully in Australia.

(2) We do not have a ready basis for determining repatriation costs for all categories of removals given many areas of the Department are involved in different aspects of removals. For example there are a wide range of other activities undertaken within the compliance program (such as employer awareness, program integrity checking, visa cancellation and the investigation and location of overstayers). However, an answer to a previous Parliamentary Question on this issue in June 2002 estimated removal costs for 9,852 persons (excluding unauthorised boat arrivals) in the first eleven months of the 2001-02 financial year was $14 million. This equates to an average of $1421 per removee. These costs include, among other things, airfares and where applicable, costs of escorts.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs and Trade: Legal Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3181 and 3183)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 1 March 2004:

question.para: (1) How much did the Minister's department spend during 2002-2003 on outsourced (a) barristers and (b) solicitors (including private firms, the Australian Government Solicitor, and any others).
(2) How much did the Minister's department spend on internal legal services.
(3) What is the Minister's department's projected expenditure on legal services for the 2003-2004 financial year.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Minister for Trade and myself, the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) All barristers' costs are invoiced through the instructing solicitor's firm.

(b) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade spent $1,320,998 on outsourced solicitor's fees (including barrister's fees) in Australia in 2002-03. It is not possible to determine expenditure by the Department's overseas missions on outsourced solicitors and barristers fees without undertaking a highly resource-intensive exercise.
(2) The cost of internal legal services undertaken by legally qualified staff in the Legal Branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in 2002-03 was $1,449,115.

(3) As at April 2004, projected expenditure on outsourced legal services by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Australia and by overseas missions of the Department is not expected to exceed $2,895,490. This figure includes estimated expenditure on legal services by overseas missions and this expenditure generally varies significantly from year to year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 9 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Did he see the article by Peter Wilmoth titled “Plans to chop Radio National” in the “Sunday Age” on 7 March 2004.
(2) Can he confirm that part of the report stating that, according to a senior ABC executive, the axing of ABC Radio National has been considered by ABC management to save money; if not, why not.
(3) Can he confirm that part of the report to the effect that this issue is almost certain to be revisited by ABC management in budget talks in the next two months; if not, why not.
(4) Will he make a statement to the House to the effect that the Government will ensure that funding for the ABC's Radio National is secure; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) No. The ABC has advised that there was absolutely no truth to the Wilmoth report that the Director of Radio proposed the axing of Radio National in last year's budget negotiations.
(3) No. The ABC has advised that there is no intention to propose the closure of Radio National in its budget discussions.

(4) The ABC's internal budget allocation is a matter for the ABC Board and management. In the 2003-04 Budget, the Government maintained the ABC's triennial funding in real terms and renewed additional funding for Radio Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 10 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Did he see the article by Mr Michael Sainsbury titled `Post pushes the envelope' in The Australian on 9 March 2004.
(2) Is he aware of the comment by Macquarie Bank analyst Mr Tim Smart that “Telstra sees its growth in media rather than its traditional telecommunications business”.

(3) Can he confirm that Telstra's purchase of the Trading Post Group is its third acquisition in the past year after its purchase of the City Search website and last week's move to buy the information technology services company Invizage; if not, why not.
(4) Can he explain how Telstra's purchase of the Trading Post Group (a) serves the public interest, and (b) meets the terms of Telstra's Customer Service Charter.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) I am aware that Telstra announced the purchase of the Australian operations of the Trading Post Group by Sensis, Telstra's advertising, information and directories business, on 8 March 2004. I am also aware that Sensis announced the purchase of a majority shareholding in Invizage on 2 March 2004. I am advised that Telstra purchased CitySearch on 23 May 2002.
(4) While Telstra is partially Government owned, it is an independent corporation and its Board and management are responsible for its commercial operations, including its investment strategies.

(a) Telstra has stated in a media release dated 8 March 2004 that the acquisition the Australian operations of the Trading Post Group meets Telstra's investment criteria, in that it will be cashflow positive in the first year, earnings per share (EPS) accretive in year 2, provides full operational control, and delivers earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation
(EBITDA) uplift. Telstra also indicated it is expecting the purchase to deliver significant value to Telstra shareholders.
(b) Telstra has advised that the purchase of the Australian operations of the Trading Post Group has no impact on Telstra's Customer Service Charter.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 31 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article by Jason Koutsoukis in The Age on 30 March 2004 titled “Williams sets sights on `raw deal' mobile phone operators” which reported that he had expressed the hope that he might soon negotiate sweeping changes to Australia's cross-media ownership laws, and that the Labor Party and the Democrats oppose changes to cross-media laws on the basis that they could lead to a further concentration of media assets in the hands Kerry Packer's Publishing and Broadcasting and Rupert Murdoch's News Limited companies.

(2) Can he indicate whether he is now prepared to accept the amendment to the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 moved by Senator Harradine in the Senate last year that would prohibit a media proprietor from owning both a television network and a newspaper in mainland capital cities of Australia; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) The Government has rejected Senator Harradine's amendment to the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002.
Excluding newspaper and television combinations in the metropolitan markets would deny companies the benefits of cross-media reform in the very markets where the range of voices is greatest.

Denying Australian media proprietors the opportunity to achieve cross-media efficiencies in the two largest media sectors will inhibit their ability to be competitive on an international stage and to invest in foreign markets. This is particularly the case when countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States are amending or repealing their cross-media laws, giving their domestic firms a significant comparative advantage.

The amendment would also prohibit our largest media groups from responding to the overseas entrants into the Australian media market that would accompany the removal of the foreign investment limits proposed in the Bill.

The amendment would also have the effect of preventing companies that own a television station from establishing a new newspaper in the same market, including, for example, a second newspaper in one of the smaller metropolitan capitals.

The proposed requirements for editorial separation, the national `2 out of 3' limit, the minimum number of media groups test, the existing limits on the number of commercial broadcasting licences a person can control in the same licence area and the competition protections of the Trade Practices Act 1974 provide strong protection against a single player becoming dominant within a market, or across platforms.
